channel.title: Hyblan's technical writing
channel.description: RSS feed for Hyblan's technical writing

item.title: Using a Markov chain to generate readable nonsense with 20 lines of Python
item.description: Describes a simple Markov chain algorithm to generate reasonable-sounding but utterly nonsensical text, and presents some example outputs as well as a Python implementation.

item.title: How (not) to apply for a software job
item.description: Advice for how to (and how not to) apply for a software engineering job, particularly for the written parts of the interview process. As a bonus, some tips for your resume/CV.

item.title: The AWK book's 60-line version of Make
item.description: A discussion of the minimal version of Make included in 'The AWK Programming Language', as well as a Python port of the AWK program.

item.title: Using the WordStar diamond in 2023
item.description: Describes the WordStar diamond, a wonderful set of key bindings from the 1970s, and how you can use it in 2023 on Linux or Windows.

item.title: Name before type: why 'age int' is better than 'int age'
item.description: A variable's name is more important than its type, so the name should be more prominent and come first in declarations.

item.title: The proposal to enhance Go's HTTP router
item.description: A brief look at the proposed enhancements to the Go standard library HTTP request router, net/http.ServeMux: matching on HTTP method, and supporting wildcards in matched paths.

item.title: Scripting with Go: a 400-line Git client that can create a repo and push itself to GitHub
item.description: In which I rewrite my toy pygit client in Go to see how suitable Go is for simple scripts.

item.title: Names should be as short as possible while still being clear
item.description: Short, meaningful names that take context into account are better than long, verbose names that don't.

item.title: Lookup Tables (Forth Dimensions XIX.3)
item.description: An article about lookup tables in Forth that I co-authored with Hans Bezemer (creator of 4tH) when I was 16.

item.title: For Python packages, file structure != API
item.description: When designing Python packages, decoupling the file structure from the package's API makes your package easier to import and use.

item.title: Designing Pythonic library APIs
item.description: Principles I've found useful for designing good Python library APIs, including structure, naming, error handling, and type annotations.

item.title: From Go on EC2 to Fly.io: +fun, âˆ’$9/mo
item.description: How I switched hosting my Go-based side projects from Amazon EC2 to Fly.io, significantly simplified deployment, and saved a bit of cash while I was at it.

item.title: Code coverage for your AWK programs
item.description: This article describes GoAWK's code coverage support, which was contributed by Volodymyr Gubarkov.

item.title: I/O is no longer the bottleneck
item.description: In 2022, disk I/O is very fast, and not usually the performance bottleneck in programs. This article digs into some numbers.

item.title: microPledge: our startup that (we wish) competed with Kickstarter
item.description: What our crowdfunding startup microPledge was, why it failed, and what we learned from the process.

item.title: Rob Pike's simple C regex matcher in Go
item.description: Translating Rob Pike's simple and elegant C regex matcher to Go.

item.title: Tools I use to build my website
item.description: How I build my website hyblan.com with GitHub Pages, Jekyll, a simple HTML+CSS layout, Sublime Text, and Sublime Merge.

item.title: Modernizing AWK, a 45-year old language, by adding CSV support
item.description: Why and how I added proper CSV support to GoAWK, my POSIX-compatible AWK interpreter.

item.title: Prig: like AWK, but uses Go for "scripting"
item.description: Describes Prig, which is for Processing Records In Go. It's a text processing tool like AWK, but it uses Go as the scripting language.

item.title: Go performance from version 1.2 to 1.18
item.description: Shows how much the performance of Go has improved from version 1.2 through to 1.18 -- in its compiler, runtime, and libraries.

item.title: Optimizing GoAWK with a bytecode compiler and virtual machine
item.description: How I sped up GoAWK by switching from a tree-walking interpreter to a bytecode compiler and virtual machine interpreter.

item.title: AWKGo, an AWK-to-Go compiler
item.description: A discussion of AWKGo, a simple compiler that translates a useful subset of the AWK text processing language into Go source code.

item.title: Improving the code from the official Go RESTful API tutorial
item.description: My re-implementation of the code from the official Go tutorial 'Developing a RESTful API with Go and Gin', using only the standard library, adding tests, and fixing issues.

item.title: Simple Lists: a tiny to-do list app written the old-school way (server-side Go, no JS)
item.description: Simple Lists is a tiny to-do list web application written in Go, with old school server-side rendering and no JavaScript.

item.title: Structural pattern matching in Python 3.10
item.description: A critical but informative look at the new structural pattern matching feature in Python 3.10, with real-world code examples.

item.title: Mugo, a toy compiler for a subset of Go that can compile itself
item.description: An overview of Mugo, a single-pass compiler for a tiny subset of the Go programming language -- just enough to compile itself.

item.title: How to implement a hash table (in C)
item.description: An explanation of how to implement a simple hash table data structure, with code and examples in the C programming language.

item.title: Performance comparison: counting words in Python, Go, C++, C, AWK, Forth, and Rust
item.description: Performance comparison of counting and sorting word frequencies in various languages (Python, Go, C++, C, AWK, Forth, Rust, and others).

item.title: The small web is beautiful
item.description: A vision for the "small web", small software, and small architectures. Also, a bonus rant about microservices.

item.title: Coming in Go 1.16: ReadDir and DirEntry
item.description: A look at the new os.ReadDir function and os.DirEntry interface coming in Go 1.16, with a comparison to os.scandir in Python.

item.title: Fuzzing in Go
item.description: An overview of fuzz testing and the go-fuzz tool, as well as a look at the recent draft design for including fuzz testing in the `go` tool (LWN.net).

item.title: Searching code with Sourcegraph
item.description: A look at Sourcegraph, a code search and code intelligence tool (LWN.net).

item.title: Different approaches to HTTP routing in Go
item.description: Compares routing techniques in Go, including five custom approaches and three using third-party routing libraries.

item.title: Go filesystems and file embedding
item.description: A presentation of the Go draft designs for a filesystem interface and a standard way to embed files in a Go binary (LWN.net).

item.title: The sad, slow-motion death of Do Not Track
item.description: Talks about the valiant but almost-dead 10-year effort to prevent tracking with the Do Not Track header.

item.title: What's new in Lua 5.4
item.description: An overview of the new features in Lua 5.4 (LWN.net).

item.title: Hugo: a static-site generator
item.description: An overview of Hugo, a flexible static website generator written in Go and optimized for speed (LWN.net).

item.title: Generics for Go
item.description: Gives some background, the current state, and potential timeline for including generics in the Go programming language (LWN.net).

item.title: More alternatives to Google Analytics
item.description: Looks at some heavier replacements for Google Analytics, as well as the GoAccess log-based analytics tool (LWN.net).

item.title: Lightweight Google Analytics alternatives
item.description: Discusses what Google Analytics tracks, and presents two lightweight alternatives: GoatCounter and Plausible (LWN.net).

item.title: An intro to Go for non-Go developers
item.description: A brief introduction to Go for programmers who haven't used Go before: Why use it? The standard library. And the language itself.

item.title: ZZT in Go (using a Pascal-to-Go converter)
item.description: Describes my port of Adrian Siekierka's "Reconstruction of ZZT" to Go, done in a semi-automated way using a Pascal-to-Go converter.

item.title: Testing in Go: philosophy and tools
item.description: Describes the minimalist philosophy of testing in Go and the built-in testing tools (LWN.net).

item.title: The state of the AWK
item.description: Surveys the AWK landscape, looks at new features in GNU Awk, and discusses why AWK is still relevant in 2020 (LWN.net).

item.title: What's coming in Go 1.15
item.description: An overview of what's coming in the Go 1.15 final release in August 2020 (LWN.net).

item.title: Don't try to sanitize input. Escape output.
item.description: Why you shouldn't try to sanitize user input; instead, escape output correctly.

item.title: SEO for Software Engineers
item.description: The basics of Search Engine Optimization, written for software developers.
